entry.title: The best coffee in Salem, Oregon
entry.summary:
It may be surprising, but we have a surprisingly good selection of coffee here in Salem, Oregon. We have several quality coffee shops and some great roasters in town.

For a few months now, we have been getting our coffee from Joseph Penner at Steel Bridge Coffee - and it's the best coffee we've come across here, for several reasons:

  • Steel Bridge is a completely local coffee roasting company in Salem, Oregon. Joseph even roasts on a roaster built in Oregon.
  • Bicycle Delivery. Our coffee shows up every Tuesday afternoon on our doorstep in a jar and it's delivered by bicycle. How awesome is that?
  • As you know, the best coffee comes from the freshest beans. Joseph puts it best on his website: "We bicycle-deliver whole bean coffee to your doorstep on the day that it was roasted (RAIN or SHINE)." Try finding coffee that fresh anyplace else in town.
  • Quality roasting. Joseph is a student of the craft and writes in detail about his coffee roasting experiences on his website. He buys and roasts coffee from various places around the world and is attentive to the differences in coffee from region to region. He enjoys educating his customers about coffee as well.
  • Cost: I can go to the grocery store and get a bag of coffee roasted three months ago if I'm lucky. Or I can get fresh roasted coffee delivered for almost the same price.

Joseph delivers whole bean coffee only. You'll need a grinder. If you just use a drip machine, a blade grinder is adequate. But for more flexibility (a French press is a great way to make coffee) you'll definitely prefer spending a little extra on a decent burr grinder. A burr grinder produces a much more even grind and I wouldn't use a French press without it.

So if you're in Salem, Oregon and you're trying to find the best coffee you can get in your home or business, check out Steel Bridge Coffee and give it a try.

entry.title: Want a free TV?
entry.summary:
Edit: The TV is spoken for already. It took less than 10 minutes. That was quick.

We're going TV-free - and to celebrate, we're giving away a free TV (you see what I did there?).

You probably don't want this. It's not new, light, or sleek. It's one more thing to use up space in your room and time in your life. Hopefully, there's someone around you who is more important to you than watching another sitcom on a standard-def, 27-inch CRT. Heck, in order to even get over-the-air reception, you'll need to get one of those analog-to-digital converter boxes. And an antenna.

Hopefully all this kind of explains why we're getting rid of it. To boil it down, we just don't need it. We'd rather spend time with the baby and each other. We don't particularly use it except for sports and (sometimes) news, and those can be done on the computer if we need. At some point we'll need to figure out how to handle the Olympics.

So we're really giving it away, but you'll need to act quickly if you do want it (for whatever reason). Otherwise we'll be taking it to Goodwill within the next couple days.

entry.title: Letters to the Editor
entry.summary:
OK, time for a quick fun post that has nothing to do with anything.

Over time, I've collected a few funny letters to the editor. All the ones shown here are from the World in Coos Bay, Oregon. I decided it was time to share some. Enjoy!

Letter 1: Editor is in the Jaws of Stupidity

"Jaws of Stupidity" - now there's a good metaphor. I've got to remember to use that one sometime. This letter, which appears to be in response to an editorial by Kathy Erickson (the then-editor of the newspaper), is very strongly written but doesn't really appear to say anything. Not anything comprehensible, at least.

Also worth noting: That wasn't a great day for letters all around. So click the image below for BIGGER! I didn't want to crop out the other letters.

Letter 2: What really caused the Feb. 7th storm?

I'm not sure what kind of world this guy thinks he lives in. I wonder what Peter DeFazio thought.

Letter 3: Enjoying a sunny, soothing interlude

Ah, a breath of fresh air and positivity in the midst of so much turmoil. I'm glad this person is happy and carefree. I was just thinking, when I wake up in the morning and I'm in a good mood, the first thing I want to do is write a letter to the editor to tell 60,000 people that I'm happy.

Letter 4: A Bavarian eatery would be nice in North Bend

It seems there's a fairly sizeable group of people in North Bend (probably mostly in the 85+ age group) that feel that their city is perfect and Coos Bay is constantly plotting to take over (consolidating the two cities has appeared on several ballots and would probably make economic sense for both cities and the larger region).

This person, though, has found something that North Bend needs: a Bavarian restaurant. Apparently, they can prove that there is no Bavarian restaurant by listing EVERY OTHER kind of restaurant that IS in North Bend. The overall effect is that this person had a little trouble staying on topic.

entry.title: Cycling over Bear Camp Road
entry.summary:
So, last Thursday I rode my bike from Gold Beach to Indian Mary Park, near Merlin, near Grants Pass Oregon.

This was not easy.

Edit to add - if you're arriving at this article from an online search: Bear Camp Road is a one and a half lane wide paved forest service road between Agness, OR and Galice, OR. It follows a large ridge between these two towns. It reaches an elevation of nearly 4,800 feet and should not be traversed in the winter (though local people frequently travel part of the distance to get to snow or for work-related reasons). During the summer it recieves quite a bit of use from rafters and other people traveling between Gold Beach and Grants Pass.

I started at Gold Beach High School around 8:00 a.m. It was a beautiful morning, but quite windy. I looped around the Gold Beach airstrip, up to the highway, and out Jerry's Flat Road toward Agness. This is the route used by the Ride the Rogue event in September, which I can HIGHLY recommend after doing this ride. This was my favorite part of the ride, beautiful and a very rideable road. It's capped off near Agness with a long (and fun) descent to a great bridge. The pavement is great for riding, lots of patches but pretty smooth overall.

A couple miles after the bridge, I took a right turn on Bear Camp Road. Here the fun begins. It's a 16-mile uphill from the river to the Bear Camp overlook at around 4,800 feet up in the Klamath Mountains. There are a lot of beautiful views but the miles tick by slowly. There are two overlooks: the Siskiyou overlook about 10 miles up the hill (near milepost 26; the mileposts are painted on the road and start at the eastern end) and the Bear Camp overlook 16 miles up the hill (at milepost 21). The road is windy and steep in places, with only a little relief from time to time. Pavement is good, with some cracks & patches but overall great for riding. There are a few very short gravel stretches, maybe a total of 1/4 mile on gravel over the entire road.

After a nice stop at the Bear Camp Overlook (where I ate some food in the car due to being bombed by gigantic flies) I took off for a 21-mile mostly-downhill ride to the Galice area. There's a little uphill on this stretch but nothing too bad. After a while I passed out of the Siskiyou National Forest and the road goes to county maintenance, and the nice smooth pavement changes over to a kind of rough chip seal.

Most of the downhill was great, but the worst part was from milepost 8 to milepost 4 where the road basically drops straight down the side of a cliff (actually "straight" is a bad word, it's really curvy). I'm not one to just coast down this kind of stuff at 50 mph, especially with the chip seal, so I was leaning on the brakes for a while. After milepost 4 things get much better.

I hear talk of a "shoe tree" but didn't see it.

I was pretty spent at the bottom of the hill but wanted to ride along the Rogue River for a while again. It was hot enough, and I was sore enough, that we decided to call it good at Indian Mary Park.

Total mileage: 72

One more time: See some pics! Click the "Photo Gallery" link at left.

entry.title: Back from California!
entry.summary:
We're back from our California trip.

This trip was a LOT of driving, but we saw lots of stuff. Most of my pictures are of Red Rock Canyon state park in the Mojave Desert, and Sequoia National Park. Evelyn and I skipped Yosemite this time - probably not a good decision but we really needed to get home; and we'd rather spend a little more time with Yosemite.

Overall, Californians were pretty rude on the road, but nice in person. They were happy to help out an Oregonian who was having trouble pumping gas.

Funniest vanity license plate: "THE NERD"

Funniest city names: "Yreka" and "Chowchilla"

Funniest city slogan: "Mojave: The Gateway to Space". I thought that was a pretty bold claim - some towns are happy with just being the "gateway to the coast".

Biggest farm town in the world: Fresno (480,000 - the same size as Sacramento)

Most lacking: Coffee shops (it was pulling teeth to even find a Starbucks in the whole state)

Replacement for coffee shops: Liquor stores, they're like coffee up here.

Amount of fun it is to drive to LA on Dodger game night: Zero

Number of rides at Six Flags Magic Mountain that Evelyn can do before she gets sick: 3

Number of rides for Aaron: He didn't even try, he went to Red Rock canyon instead where he could, well, stay on the ground

Miles logged: 2,300

entry.title: R2CB!
entry.summary:
Roseburg to Coos Bay Relay was last weekend. I ran on a team with my family (all except David). Here's how things went:

  1. Drive to Coos Bay on Friday afternoon and watch the Coos County track meet. Eat some dinner.
  2. Wake up at 4:00 a.m. This run had better be a LOT of fun.
  3. Leave at 4:30 a.m. to drive to Roseburg in time for our 7:00 start.
  4. Start! My mom takes leg 1 out toward Lookingglass in the cool overcast weather. At least it's dry. Leg 1 is mostly uphill.
  5. We see a jeep drive by like three times during leg 2 (Dad) and leg 3 (Steph). On my leg (4), I see it being towed.
  6. I run leg 4. Still cloudy and cold. Leg 4 is flat at first, then starts going up... it goes up for a while, then downhill, then up again on a steeper hill. Overall not an easy leg, but I felt pretty good and did fine powering up the hill.
  7. Corey has leg 5. Ha ha ha ha ha! This is a nasty hill.
  8. Mom takes over on leg 6. This finishes off the hill from leg 5 and then goes downhill on the other side. The Coquille River starts up here, as a little trickle becoming a stream. The road changes to gravel and the clouds cleared off on this leg. For the rest of the run, it was sunny and really warm, although it cooled off a bit as we approached the coast of course.
  9. As Dad is running leg 7, we're driving down the gravel road in the middle of the forest, with waterfalls along the ever-growing Coquille River.
  10. We pick up some pavement on Steph's downhill leg 8.
  11. My leg 9 is flat, short, and hot. I didn't feel very good on this one. Not looking forward to the next one.
  12. After Corey's leg, Mom has a fun leg: 2 miles up, 2 miles down. Another runner was looking at the gentle slope rising from the exchange point, she said, "is it like this the whole way up?" Not really... she reaches the top of the hill spewing expletives... Mom says, "well, the last half mile was pretty steep, I guess".
  13. Fairview! Everyone's stopping at the store since it's the first one we've seen for hours. But Coos Bay is just over the hill..
  14. Up Blue Ridge, and down the other side on the gravel road to Sumner. Almost time for me to run my third leg...
  15. I get to run my last leg on the rolling hills from Sumner to the big hill I used to run several times a week to get to my house... I felt great, charged over the top of the big hill and down Ross Inlet Road.
  16. Corey finishes off by running into Eastside then Coos Bay and finishing at Freddy's.
  17. Time to get some 'za at Abby's. We were third in our division in 9:27:26.

entry.title: New Salem bridge!
entry.summary:
The old railroad bridge over the Willamette River has been converted to a pedestrian/bike bridge and is open now! It connects Riverfront Park and Wallace Marine Park. Riverfront Park is a grassy park with a carousel and wide concrete walking paths, and lots of community festivals and things are held there; Wallace Marine is a little more wild and has a reputation as the location of several homeless camps. Hopefully the increased foot and bike traffic in the area - along with city and volunteer efforts to clean out some undergrowth and maintain running trails in the park - will make the park a more pleasant place to be.

As you can see, the bridge isn't much of a looker, but it's nice to have.

Even though it doesn't look beautiful from a distance, it's not unpleasant when you're there.

There's a lead paint issue on the bridge, it's flaking off on places like this. It's been sealed 6-8 feet above the walkway, the picture here shows an area above that. As far as I know, the bridge will be closed over next winter so the issue can be taken care of.

Hey, Salem's got something cool now! In your FACE, Bend!

entry.title: Fruit on the Bottom - a yogurt review
entry.summary:
As I sit here eating a cup of yogurt, it occurs to me: Who invented fruit-on-the-bottom yogurt? Is it good? Of course, I have an opinion about this.

Now, I'm not generally an "instant-gratification, I-want-everything-right-now" kind of guy. But I can't help but think that the fruit is put on the bottom simply to add an extra layer of preparation before I can enjoy my yogurt. I not only have to remove the lid and weird little foil thing, I have to stir the fruit into the yogurt. Sometimes, I rush the stirring a little too much, and end up spilling a glob of yogurt on the table, floor, or myself (yeah, I can hear you snickering already. This is purely an indictment of the yogurt companies, or as I call them, "Big Yogurt"; this has nothing to do with my strengths and weaknesses as a yogurt stirrer). Let's face it: Fruit-on-the-bottom is a poor user interface design for yogurt cups.

And what's the point anyway? If I stir the fruit into the yogurt, I've just spent an extra 30 seconds to bring my yogurt up to "blended yogurt" standards. The stirring (in my opinion) ruins the consistency and temperature of the yogurt and it's impossible to stir it up evenly anyways. There's always too much fruit left in the bottom. If I wanted my yogurt and fruit separate, I'd eat a bunch of plain yogurt then a couple spoonfuls of jam or a pineapple or something.

I am only one voice, but if enough of us speak up, Big Yogurt will eventually have to listen.

entry.title: We're back!
entry.summary:
We're back from our trip to Bend. It was a great trip. The weather was amazing (80's and sunny the whole time) and Bend seems like a pretty cool town. We have a few pictures up, just click "pictures" above.

Here's a quick run-down of the trip (links are to Google maps of trails):

Thursday: After arriving in Bend, we ran the First Street Rapids trail. This starts just a few blocks from downtown and is a dirt/gravel trail along the Deschutes river with views of mountains. Bend has lots of these kinds of trails within a few minutes of town. Thursday's dinner was at the McMenamin's downtown.

Friday's coffee was Bend Mountain Coffee. The run was atShevlin Park, a city park along the west end of town. It's got trails through the forest and feels further out than it really is. Dinner was Pizza Mondo.

Saturday's coffee was Maui Wowi (yes, that's what it is really called). Good coffee! Evelyn ran a trail from Larkspur Park to Pilot Butte, then up the butte, then cooled down back to the park. Again, it's cool that Bend has these trails in town. Dinner was... let's see... dinner was Bella Cucina, a little Italian restaurant in the Old Mill District.

Sunday's coffee was the Strictly Organic Coffee House. We ran at Shevlin Park again and stopped for smoothies from Maui Wowi on our way back into town. Dinner was Toomie's, a Thai restaurant downtown.

Monday's coffee was Backporch Coffee. They roast their own coffee and have some interesting blends. We ran on the Deschutes River Trail south of town. This was only a 10-minute drive from town! Shevlin Park was even closer. Did I mention that we were impressed with how much trail running there is in Bend? Dinner was at a seafood chain restaurant called Anthony's. It was nice!

Tuesday's coffee was Bellatazza. We then packed our stuff and left town. On the way back, we stopped in Sisters and ran the Eagle Rock Loop. And now we're home! And it's cloudy again!
